comment._content: Baker's Lane/Road.......It's unrecognizable today. The only building I can see that still exists is that two story house with the three windows over a window.(dispensary on Osi ) Street view OSI (1903)

comment._content: I wonder if the young boy with the bucket is there to collect "goodies" for his mothers rose garden?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Checked in the Guy's Directories. No sign of Meadowvale in 1904, 1905, 1907 or 1908. We don't have 1906.

Meadowvale first appears in 1909 and again until 1912, only disappearing in the 1913 volume.

Meadowvale Dairy Company was listed under Dairy Factories and Butter Exporters. The manager was a J. Fant.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: I never tasted milk delivered like that. But I remember getting milk in glass bottles as a kid. Nothing better!

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content: The establishment of dairy co-operatives like this one is generally held to have disadvantaged women; it was they who ,before this, looked after the calf, milked the cow, soured the milk before turning it into butter in a churn and finished the process by washing and salting the butter. The co-operatives removed the money they made by doing this.
